text: Sorry for the late reply! Crazy week...

Matte painting is an interesting discipline. At One of Us at least, our matte painters do a few things. Most of the time they're in Photoshop painting backgrounds for our shots (it also includes a lot of photo-manipulation, like classic "photoshopping", where you mush different photos together to make a scene). They work on everything from the realistic to the more fantastical backdrops. It's usually "background" stuff in that it's far enough away not to have to build it in 3D, but that doesn't mean it's not important - often times a DMP can take up half the screen or more.

The other thing our DMP artists do (though this isn't the case everywhere) is concept art. Recently they've been working on magical beasts, evil science labs and creepy, realistic puppets. That's also in Photoshop.

However, more often, the DMP artists are overlapping with 3D environments too. They're building fairly simple 3D geo which they can use as a perspective guide, but to also project their matte paintings onto so that they can get parallax.
Does this sound interesting to you? Here's our Crown showreel - a lot of our city and countryside backgrounds are all or partially DMP: <https://vimeo.com/248127865>
